resharedPost.text:
We‚Äôre thrilled to announce that Pear Suite has raised $7.6 million in Series A funding to power community health workers (CHWs) and community-based organizations (CBOs) nationwide.

This round was led by Rock Health Capital and Nexxus Holdings, with major support from Mucker Capital, Enable Ventures, The SCAN Foundation, and Acumen America, Impact Engine, and California Health Care Foundation. Open Venture Capital, Incisive Ventures, and 7BC Venture Capital also participated in the round.

With this funding, we‚Äôll:
- Expand our AI-powered platform to help thousands of CHWs and CBOs deliver trust-based, culturally rooted care.
- 10x our provider network to reach more people through health plan partnerships.
- Deepen our work with Medicaid and Medicare plans to make community-based care sustainable and scalable.

This milestone is a testament to our customers, community partners, and industry allies who continue to believe in what we‚Äôre building; our amazing staff for their hard work and dedication; and our co-founders, Colby R. Takeda and Nick Lockett, for their visionary leadership. When innovation grows from trust, health equity becomes unstoppable.

Read the full press release: https://lnkd.in/guWpUE8Z

#PearSuite #SeriesA #DigitalHealth #HealthEquity #CHWs #CBOs #Medicaid #Medicare #AIinHealthcare #SocialDriversofHealth

data.text:
In a healthcare system that‚Äôs often hard to navigate, Community Health Workers (CHWs) and community-based organizations (CBOs) make it human again.

Proud to share that Pear Suite has raised $7.6M in Series A funding to expand our mission‚Äîequipping CHWs and CBOs with the tools to deliver trust-based, community-rooted care nationwide.

Grateful to our team and partners for making this possible!

resharedPost.text:
It‚Äôs my favorite month of the year... Latine Heritage Month! ‚ô•Ô∏è üíÉ 

I‚Äôm so excited to announce that I‚Äôll be speaking at the Techqueria Summit for the third year in a row, this time on ‚ÄúM√°s Que Software: A Startup Model Rooted in Collective Power‚Äù with Andrew Lindbloom. 

As I reflect on this month, I can‚Äôt ignore the reality that Latinas hold only ~1% of senior leadership roles in the U.S. tech industry. That number is why this work, and speaking at Techqueria matters so much to me. Representation isn‚Äôt just about who sits at the table, but about the systems we build and who they serve.

I‚Äôm so proud of what we‚Äôre building at Pear Suite. Even though we are a technology company on the surface, our mission is bigger than software. We empower community-based organizations like promotoras, CHWs, and doulas so they can keep doing what they do best: supporting their communities with culturally rooted care.

Representation matters. And so does building systems that reflect the voices, languages, and lived experiences of the communities we serve. I‚Äôm proud to work at the intersection of technology and community power, where we can scale not just software ‚Äî but trust, access, and care. üôå 

Want to learn more about how we are empowering the organizations in your community? Join me at Techqueria Tech Week! üì£ 
Day 2: October 2, 2025 | 3:00‚Äì3:30 PM EST / 12:00‚Äì12:30 PM PST
üîó Register here: http://bit.ly/TQsummit

#LatineHeritageMonth #TechqueriaTechWeek #TechSpeaker #EnComunidad #InCommunity #LatinaProfessionals

author.headline: Head of Operations @ Pear Suite | Health Equity Advocate & Innovator

data.text:
Representation isn‚Äôt just about who‚Äôs in the room; it‚Äôs about what the room builds.

For too long, tech has tried to solve community problems from the outside in. The most scalable approach is to build tools that empower the experts already there‚Äîbecause they know what works.

With over 63 million people in the U.S. identifying as Hispanic or Latino (19% of the total population), the future of tech and healthcare has to reflect and build with the communities driving that growth.

Excited to join Julia Garcia, MHA at the Techqueria Summit to talk about what it looks like when communities don‚Äôt just participate in innovation‚Äîthey lead it.

#HealthTech #Startups #CommunityHealth #Techqueria #LatineHeritageMonth

Our co-founder and CEO, Colby R. Takeda, will join Nora Zaragoza-Y√°√±ez (FAITH IN THE VALLEY), Andrew Lindbloom, and Diya Mittal (Pear Suite) to discuss strategies for navigating reimbursement pathways and what‚Äôs ahead for CHW programs.

#CHWs #NACHW #UnityConference #CommunityHealth #NACHWUNITY #PublicHealth

data.text:
Medicaid and Medicare reimbursement isn‚Äôt just policy‚Äîit‚Äôs infrastructure for sustainable, community-based care. CHWs are already delivering services that are billable, but most systems aren‚Äôt set up to support or scale that work.

This week at #NACHW, I‚Äôm co-presenting ‚ÄúCracking the Code on Medicaid and Medicare Reimbursement for CHWs‚Äù with Nora Zaragoza-Y√°√±ez, Diya Mittal, and Colby R. Takeda. We‚Äôll walk through how policy, workflows, and tech come together to make CHW services reimbursable‚Äîand sustainable.

If you‚Äôre focused on building systems that actually work for real people and communities, this is the conversation to be in!

#Medicaid #CHW #Medicare #CommunityBasedCare #HealthcareInnovation #NACHW2025

author.headline: CEO at Pear Suite | Champion for CHWs

data.text:
Medicaid is shifting, but one thing is clear‚Äîthe future isn‚Äôt just about policy, it‚Äôs about execution. Community-based orgs and CHWs are on the frontlines, and the right tools can make or break their ability to keep people out of the ER and connected to care.

Great to see this conversation getting national attention!

What‚Äôs next? The focus should be on scalable, sustainable solutions that bridge the gap between policy and implementation‚Äîensuring CHWs and community-based orgs have what they need to actually deliver on the promise of value-based care. Let‚Äôs build smarter.

#Medicaid #CommunityHealth #CHWs #HealthTech #ValueBasedCare

Community-based providers and organizations play a vital role in expanding access to tobacco cessation support for Medi-Cal members.

That‚Äôs why Pear Suite is excited to collaborate with UC Davis Center for Healthcare Policy and Research on this pilot project. Together, we‚Äôre supporting Community Health Worker-led outreach and referrals to Kick It California, bridging trusted local relationships with evidence-based care.

This project also centers CHW voices in program design, using real-time feedback to shape a more effective and culturally relevant approach.

If you're a CHW in California's Central Valley and want to participate, email us at community@pearsuite.com or click the link below to sign up!

https://bit.ly/CHW-tobacco

#CommunityHealth #CHWs #TobaccoCessation

data.text: When leading research institutions collaborate with community-based providers, real impact happens at scale. Thrilled to see this pilot project come to life after months of working alongside Cindy Valencia, PhD, MPH, and her team at UC Davis Health to make it a reality!

I‚Äôll be joining the ‚ÄúCharting the Course for Community Health Workers: Securing Sustainable Payment to Support Essential Services‚Äù panel alongside Maria Lemus from Visi√≥n y Compromiso, Shanteny Jackson Jackson from the Virginia Community Health Worker Association, and Lucas Allen from Partners In Health‚Äîamazing leaders in the CHW space. During the panel, we‚Äôll explore challenges in sustaining financing for this critical workforce and innovative ways to design Medicaid payments to better support the vital role of community providers in our healthcare system.

A key theme emerging at the conference is the importance of collaboration to protect and strengthen programs like Medicaid and the coverage millions of Americans rely on. resharedPost.text:
Community Health Workers (CHWs) play an increasingly critical role in the U.S. healthcare delivery system, and there is growing momentum for CHW interventions to drive even more impact on health outcomes and costs. Significant investments in workforce development and rapidly increasing Medicaid coverage for CHW services mean there is a growing CHW workforce with access to reimbursement dollars. Yet most CHWs and the community-based organizations (CBOs) that employ them have no experience submitting healthcare claims. 

This is where Pear Suite comes in. Pear Suite‚Äôs SaaS platform enables the rapidly growing CHW workforce to standardize the data they collect, improve care navigation, and access reimbursement. The company partners with payers and CBOs to address the social drivers of health in a scalable, cost-effective, and person-centered way.

Today Rock Health Capital is announcing our most recent investment in Pear Suite, alongside Flare Capital Partners, AARP, and California Health Care Foundation. Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gerrfR2u

data.text: Very exciting to be part of this work at Pear Suite!

data.text:
It‚Äôs been over a month since I graduated with my Master of Public Health in Health Policy and Management from the UC Berkeley School of Public Health. Over the past two years, I immersed myself in both classroom and industry settings, learning about the strengths and challenges of the US healthcare system. I engaged in meaningful discussions with my peers, professors, and the greater University of California, Berkeley community about how we can make healthcare more accessible, affordable, and equitable for every American and what each of us can do in our respective fields to make that a reality.

When I started the program, I had my own ideas about the issues in the US healthcare system and the stakeholders involved. My perspectives were challenged and enriched by insights from community advocates, policymakers, and industry leaders rethinking healthcare delivery. Recent global events, such as pandemics, wars, political instability, and challenges to democracy, underscore the urgent need for competent and effective leaders who take action to address inequities and injustices. I aspire to become one of those leaders.

I‚Äôm excited to share that I‚Äôll be continuing my journey at Pear Suite, an industry leader in addressing SDOH and supporting care navigation, as Health Policy Lead. In this role, I‚Äôll engage in the incredible work of Community Health Workers (CHWs) across America and help empower a workforce that supports individuals and alleviates some of the burdens on our healthcare system. I‚Äôm really looking forward to this next chapter!

Thank you to my family, friends, peers, professors, supervisors, and coworkers for their endless support! A special thanks to Colby R. Takeda for his tremendous mentorship and trust in my capabilities, and to the rest of the Pear Suite team.

author.headline: Director of AI Deployment & Success @ Assort Health - Specialty-specific voice AI to answer patient calls

We dove into everything from boosting Medicaid systems to helping young entrepreneurs and bringing new technology tools to community partners. I also shared insights on how Pear Suite initiatives are contributing to health equity by empowering community health workers and supporting sustainable revenue models for paraprofessionals. Big thanks to Ariel Rose Cooper, MPH!

resharedPost.text:
By 2030, more than 73 million Americans will pass the age of 65. Two-thirds of them will suffer from two or more chronic diseases; creating a public health challenge dubbed ‚Äúthe 2030 problem.‚Äù  Researchers in the field of public health are exploring¬† ways that chronic diseases might be prevented through innovations in healthcare services and systems. 

To create solutions for the health problems faced by an aging population, Berkeley Public Health is launching the new Berkeley Center for Health Innovations and Entrepreneurship. With a $10 million gift from the Qianlong Holding Group, the new center will serve as a hub to bring together faculty from across the UC Berkeley campus ‚Äî along with innovators and entrepreneurs from around the globe.

https://lnkd.in/gPwuWrwi

#HealthTechnology #PublicHealth #HealthCare #AI #UCBerkeley #BerkeleyPublicHealth

company.name: UC Berkeley School of Public Health

data.text: Very exciting news out of UC Berkeley School of Public Health! Through my experiences at Berkeley Public Health and Pear Suite , I've come to recognize the pivotal role of innovation and entrepreneurial leadership within the realm of public health professionals. In the contemporary healthcare landscape, an array of fresh players, including many from the tech sector, have stepped into the arena. It is imperative for the teams at the forefront of driving innovation and crafting solutions to address our nation's critical challenges while embracing a public health mindset that prioritizes health equity and social justice for all.

I initially joined Pear Suite as a Graduate Intern, and during that time, I had the privilege of witnessing the impactful work this SaaS platform does in supporting health organizations and community-based efforts to enhance individual well-being. I want to thank Colby R. Takeda and the rest of the Pear Suite team for a great summer experience. As I continue with Pear Suite in my new role as Project Lead, I'm looking forward to both personal growth and contributing to the organization's ongoing mission and goals. The future holds exciting possibilities, and I'm eager to be a part of them.

data.text:
New data analytics tools are changing how people make decisions and relate to one another. Exploring how this trend affects human behavior in the workplace is one of the many fascinating and important research studies taking place at the Harvard Business School. 

This past summer, I had the privilege of working closely with HBS faculty through a research fellowship at the HBS Program for Research in Markets and Organizations (PRIMO). The program included rigorous weekly research presentations, the HBS case study experience, and workshops, all of which have honed my research skills and provided a much richer understanding of what a career in business academia looks like. I want to thank the program coordinators, Maryna MacDonald and Marais Canali Young, for planning and executing such a terrific summer research experience and for investing their time and efforts in ensuring our success.

author.headline: Director of AI Deployment & Success @ Assort Health - Specialty-specific voice AI to answer patient calls

data.text:
The Tsimane‚Äô are a unique forager-horticultural society mostly known for their robust cardiovascular and metabolic health. Much of their good health is tied to their traditional culture, which includes the prioritization to relational and embodied wealth, as opposed to material wealth. 

This summer I had the unique privilege of working with demographic and social network data from a Tsimane‚Äô village to research the social networks of forager-horticulturalists entering the market economy. As a Ronald E. McNair Scholar, I worked along with Alan Schultz, Ph.D., MPH, in developing this project, composing a manuscript, and a poster. I also had the opportunity to present my research at a virtual conference here at Baylor University.

I want to thank Dr. Schultz for his guidance and mentorship throughout the research and writing process. I thank the Santa Maria village for welcoming Dr. Schultz into their community and working along with the field school research team to gather unique data. I thank the Ronald E. McNair Post-Baccalaureate Achievement Program at Baylor University for funding this research project. Lastly, I thank Dr. Ronald McNair for his story and legacy. #ronaldmcnairscholar #baylor #research #publichealth #tsimane' #sna #socialnetworkstructure #marketintegration

resharedPost.text:
5 ways COVID-19 has changed work for the better.

1. Having very important business meetings from our kitchen tables (with dogs and kids playing in the background) will help everyone remember we're all human, and we have real lives. 

2. Soon, most white & grey collar jobs will be remote by default and onsite by choice. This will be a boon to working parents, and may help close the gender pay gap. 

3. Our inability to look over our employee's shoulder will force us to build trust with our team, or finally realize we hired the wrong person. 

4. Rather than living close to work and far from family, people will start living close to family and far from work. 

5. As lost jobs and fear of infection help us see how short and sweet life is, many of us will finally stop working dead-end jobs, and start pursuing our passions. 

Thanks Christian Hetrick in for including me in your piece last week.
